result.markdown:
--- title: "Homework 9" format: html execute: echo: false message: false warning: false --- ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Part 1 ------------------------------------------------------------------------ This part of the homework uses [Jenny Bryan](https://jennybryan.org/)'s [Lord of the Rings tidy data materials](https://github.com/jennybc/lotr-tidy).

#### 1. Create a new RStudio Project and name it `hw_9`

#### 2. Within that project, create a new Quarto document and modify the YAML to: - Include your name - Render to html - Change the syntax highlighting to any scheme but the default - Include code folding - Include a table of contents - Use level 1 headers for items (4) through (8) below - Use level 2 headers for your table and plot in (7) below - Set global chunk options for the document to display and evaluate all code, and not display any warnings or messages

#### 3. Your first code chunk should: - Be labelled `load-packages` - Load all the necessary packages (please don't load packages you do **not** use) - Include options for this code chunk so it will not display the code or the results from the code.

# 4. Your second code chunk should: - Be labelled `load-data` - Import the following three data sets, each as separate objects - *The_Fellowship_Of_The_Ring.csv* - *The_Two_Towers.csv* - *The_Return_Of_The_King.csv* - (These data sets show the **words spoken** by characters of different races and genders in the *Lord of the Ring*s movie trilogy.) - Combine these three data sets into one data set as a new object named `lotr_untidy` ::: {.cell} :::

# 5. Describe why the combined data set is not tidy. There is information in the column headings, namely sex (male, female).

# 6. Your third code chunk should: - Have a meaningful label (do not use spaces or capital letters or underscores) - Tidy the combined data set - Save the tidy data to the data folder in your project as `lotr_tidy` ::: {.cell} :::

# 7. Your fourth code chunk should include code that: - Reads in the *Female.csv* and *Male.csv* files and saves a single tidy data frame to file - This should reproduce exactly the `lotr_tidy` data from above - Compute the total number of words spoken by each race across the entire trilogy. - Show these results in a table and a figure. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {#tbl-words .cell tbl-cap='Total number of words spoken by each race across the entire LOTR trilogy'} ::: ::: {.cell} :::

#### 8. Let's make messy data. Your fifth code chunk should include code that uses `lotr_tidy` and `pivot_wider()` to: - Get one variable per `Race.` Save this as an object - Get one variable per `Gender.` Save this as an object ::: {.cell} :::



------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Part 2 ------------------------------------------------------------------------

#### 1. Tidy the *Project Reads* data - Load the **Project_Reads_Scores.csv** file - Remove columns 5-9, 24, and 25 - Filter to remove the rows in *student_id* that represent aggregate summaries - Tidy the remaining dataset such that a case represents a score and percentage within a unit (i.e., *score* and *percentage* will be separate columns). Take a VERY close look at the data. You will be able to use the `names_sep` argument if you **first** `rename()` two columns. Identify those two columns first. Also, you will need to first `pivot_longer` and then `pivot_wider` in order to tidy properly. In these data, "tidy" is a row for each of the seven *units* for every *student_id*. ::: {.cell} :::

#### 2. Produce a summary table of the mean percentage correct for each unit within test sites. Report the summary in a table. ::: {.cell} :::
